title: Multiple Sclerosis Resource Center

sections.heading: 1 of 11 / Overview
content: MS is a disease that can affect your brain and spinal cord, and can cause problems with vision, balance, muscle control.
We answer some of the most common questions about multiple sclerosis.
As you learn more about they type of MS you have, you'll have a clearer idea how it may affect you in the coming years.
Many other conditions have symptoms similar to those of MS. Your doctor will need to rule out these other conditions first.
bullets: What Is Multiple Sclerosis (MS)? MS is a disease that can affect your brain and spinal cord, and can cause problems with vision, balance, muscle control.
Frequently Asked Questions About MS We answer some of the most common questions about multiple sclerosis.

sections.heading: 2 of 11 / Types
content: There are a few types of MS. Knowing which type you have can help predict disease severity and how well treatment will work.
Most people with multiple sclerosis (MS) have a type called relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS). It usually starts in your 20s or 30s.
One study shows that people who began treatment when their first symptoms started were 35% less likely to have a repeat attack.
It's important to track your symptoms so you know when your MS progresses.
bullets: What Are the Different Types of MS? There are a few types of MS. Knowing which type you have can help predict disease severity and how well treatment will work.
Relapsing-Remitting Multiple Sclerosis Most people with multiple sclerosis (MS) have a type called relapsing-remitting MS (RRMS). It usually starts in your 20s or 30s.
Early Treatment for Relapsing-Remitting MS One study shows that people who began treatment when their first symptoms started were 35% less likely to have a repeat attack.
Why You Should Track Your RRMS Symptoms It's important to track your symptoms so you know when your MS progresses.

sections.heading: 3 of 11 / Symptoms
content: How and when symptoms like vision trouble and numbness and tingling are commonly seen.
Vision problems are pretty common for people with MS. The symptoms usually come and go on their own.
How MS cam affect the optic nerve and cause vision trouble.
Uhthoff’s phenomenon is most commonly a symptom of MS, though it can also coincide with other optic nerve disorders.
bullets: Symptoms of Multiple Sclerosis How and when symptoms like vision trouble and numbness and tingling are commonly seen.
Multiple Sclerosis and Vision Problems Vision problems are pretty common for people with MS. The symptoms usually come and go on their own.
Optic Neuritis: How MS Can Affect Your Vision How MS cam affect the optic nerve and cause vision trouble.
What Is the Uhthoff Phenomenon? Uhthoff’s phenomenon is most commonly a symptom of MS, though it can also coincide with other optic nerve disorders.

sections.heading: 4 of 11 / Causes & Risks
content: It's not known what causes MS. Many reasons could be at play, including your genes, where you live, and the air you breathe.
In basic terms, scientists simply don’t know what causes multiple sclerosis, or MS. Your genes play at least some part.
MS doesn’t have a cure, but strong evidence shows that viruses may trigger the process, especially Epstein-Barr virus.
MS and diabetes are connected because they share some of the same symptoms, and they might have some of the same causes.
bullets: Possible Causes of Multiple Sclerosis It's not known what causes MS. Many reasons could be at play, including your genes, where you live, and the air you breathe.
Your Genes and Multiple Sclerosis (MS) In basic terms, scientists simply don’t know what causes multiple sclerosis, or MS. Your genes play at least some part.

MS and Diabetes: What to Know MS and diabetes are connected because they share some of the same symptoms, and they might have some of the same causes.

sections.heading: 5 of 11 / Tests & Diagnosis
content: It can be a challenge for doctors to diagnose MS. There’s no single test that can prove you have it.
MRI is a diagnostic test that detects changes in the brain related to MS.
Liquid taken from a spinal tap is a procedure that can indicate brain-related trouble from MS.
Evoked potential tests measure electrical activity in the brain caused by light, sound, and touch.
bullets: How Multiple Sclerosis Is Diagnosed It can be a challenge for doctors to diagnose MS. There’s no single test that can prove you have it.
Diagnosing Multiple Sclerosis With MRI MRI is a diagnostic test that detects changes in the brain related to MS.
The Spinal Tap and MS Liquid taken from a spinal tap is a procedure that can indicate brain-related trouble from MS.
Evoked Potential Tests for MS Evoked potential tests measure electrical activity in the brain caused by light, sound, and touch.

sections.heading: 6 of 11 / Treatment
content: Although there's not yet a cure for MS, there are many effective medications to help you manage the disease.
Kesimpta targets a part of your immune system known as B cells. Kesimpta is a medicine used to treat relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis (MS).
These are drugs that have been shown to slow the progression of MS.
Learn about Vumerity for MS, including its benefits, side effects, and helpful tips for managing treatment.
bullets: Treatments for Multiple Sclerosis Although there's not yet a cure for MS, there are many effective medications to help you manage the disease.

sections.heading: 7 of 11 / Living With
content: A long-lasting condition like multiple sclerosis can affect your life in many ways.
There’s no at-home remedy for MS. But there are things you can do to feel better and ease your symptoms.
A cold or flu is no fun for anyone, but if you have multiple sclerosis (MS), it can mean extra trouble.
Years ago, people worried that some vaccines caused MS. Studies showed that this wasn’t true. Yet some shots may cause a relapse.
bullets: Tips for Living With MS A long-lasting condition like multiple sclerosis can affect your life in many ways.
Self-Care for MS Symptoms There’s no at-home remedy for MS. But there are things you can do to feel better and ease your symptoms.
Colds and Flu When You Have MS A cold or flu is no fun for anyone, but if you have multiple sclerosis (MS), it can mean extra trouble.
Can I Get Vaccines if I Have MS? Years ago, people worried that some vaccines caused MS. Studies showed that this wasn’t true. Yet some shots may cause a relapse.

sections.heading: 8 of 11 / Mobility & Assistive Devices
content: Assistive devices can make life with MS easier. They help with walking, dressing, and bathing, and help you use less energy.
Many gadgets and technology solutions are on the market that can help people with MS keep independence in their homes.
MS can change how well you move around and get things done. You may have to tweak how you do daily tasks to make them easier.
If your MS symptoms are making it hard for you to move around, it may be time to make a few changes to your home.

sections.heading: 9 of 11 / Complications
content: You can develop complications along with your multiple sclerosis. They can range from mild to severe.
With MS, you're more likely to have certain other medical conditions, such as depression, high blood pressure, and lung disease.
Over time, about half of people with MS can have cognitive problems. That means poor focus, slowed thinking, or fuzzy memory.
Commonly, MS can affect a part of your brain called the cerebellum. Damage here can leave you with a wide range of symptoms.

sections.heading: 10 of 11 / Caregiving & Support
content: Here are a variety of resources available to help you and your family meet the challenges of MS.
MS is a disease that can get worse over time. As your symptoms grow more severe, you may need a hand to manage your condition.
Here are questions to ask and things to look for when considering an assisted living community.
You may reach a point where your MS is too severe and the complications too numerous to keep up a good quality of life.

content: These exercises using resistance bands are designed by a physical therapist to build strength while considering the fatigue that comes with MS.

meta_description: Multiple sclerosis affects 2.5 million people worldwide, including 400,000 Americans. Get in-depth multiple sclerosis information here on symptoms and treatments of MS.
